description:
**Ok, ignore last note... Through the magic of Ibuprofen based anit-inflamitory cream and session with the Physio - I'm fixed! Good to go... GAME ON! :-) **

I might not be able to run for the time being - but i can still skate ;-)

So how about a few hours skating by the canals in Mechelen. The paths there are flat, smooth, obstacle free (away from traffic) and distance can be decided depending the group.
The aim of this is to reach out to those of you who have skates, want to skate, but are not as confident on them to tackle something like a Roller-Parade just yet. Being flat, no hills to worry about and with no major obstacles or need to have to stop rapidly, if you’re ok to skate in a straight line un-aided, then this is just the sort of practice session you need… Should be a fun relaxed pace, that will allow you to build up your confidence/skill and I’m available for any tips/advice if needs be.
Only issue will be to get there – it’s a car ride (there is a possibility to take the train to Mechelen and start there, but will need to see about timings and the additional distance this will add to the skating). I will have places in my car, but if someone else with a car is joining then all the better.
Meeting point – by the White Knight at Montgomery round-about, 6.30pm (negotiable depending the group). Will take 20-30mins to get to the start point (depending the traffic conditions), but with the light nights, we should still have a good few hours available – will try to find a bar to have a drink or grab a bite afterwards :-)
Recommend you wear a helmet and knee/elbow/wrist protections – don’t forget your skates of course and maybe a small backpack for shoes and a bottle of water ;-)
So come on – give it a try ;-)

The start point we're aiming for is:

Battelse Bergen 4,
2800 Mechelen (Google maps!)
name: Skate by the canals near Mechelen - 'part 2' - **CONFIRMED**

description: We meet by the flag under the central arche
name: a few laps around 50nnaire

description:
Spend the August long weekend in one of the most stunning regions of Norway doing a range of outdoor activities.

Check out:
http://www.visitnorway.com/en/Where-to-go/Fjord-Norway/Stavanger/What-to-do-in-the-Stavanger-Region/Attractions-in-the-Stavanger-Region/

Fly from Brussels to Stavanger via Amsterdam Wed evening and return Sunday evening. Hire a car and camp.

We booked the following flight with KLM:

Thu outbound at 6:25 via AMS, Sun inbound at 17:30 via AMS (notice that the onward journey is via Thalys but is part of the KLM package)

People may optionally arrive WED evening already.

Some details and costs are in the spread sheet:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AkGAApeFJBjIdHNJc3FEYjVVV2RTZ19aRnNkaDF0dFE#gid=0

While the flights are not cheap, we will camp and be cost conscious to offset it.
name: Trip to Norway in Aug long weekend

description:
Ok, so I’m hijacking this group to post a few skating events, but i know some of you might be interested, so I’m hoping the 'authorities' won't mind ;-)
The NRW Inline Tour is a 3 day skating tour around the countryside of Dusseldorf. The pace is relaxed (but steady) and approx. 80km per day – this is not as bad as it sounds with breaks along the way and long lunch breaks. Each day the tour ends at a pool complex where you can take a relaxing dip before enjoying a BBQ. Accommodation can be a hotel or like most, ‘camping’ in a sports hall – trust me you’ll be tired and you won’t care where you sleep! :-)
The cost includes the organisation (which being German is excellent!), breakfast, your chosen accommodation type and the facilities at the end of each day. Lunch and Dinner is extra as well is the bus transfer back to your start point if required at the end of the 3 days.
The routes are mostly flat very smooth roads, we’re flanked by police who keep the traffic away from us and (like the roller-parades in Brussels) there’s a huge truck at the front blasting out music. Your luggage is carried by truck and so you only have to carry what you want and are free to skate. A great atmosphere, and you’ll feel great after doing it! If you can skate and are fit then you should be able to do this event no problem… Last year the weather was glorious and this event was wonderful!
The site below is in German, but feel free to Google-translate or ask me if you want more info.

http://www.nrw-inlinetour.de/

Incidentally the night before the tour there is RollNacht (Dusseldorf’s equivalent to the roller-parades in Brussels) – this is a good start to the weekend (www.rollnacht.de). There are approx. 9 RollNacht dates throughout the summer and will be attending some of these too (starting May 2nd - more details to follow)

Enjoy!
Matt

 

(ps. everyone is of course in charge of their own booking/fee's. We can look at car-pooling options nearer the time...)
name: NRW Inline Tour

description: Back to the old Woluwe Park evening run: around 10 km/h, 45-60 minutes.
how_to_find_us: Our meeting point is by the pond next to Bemelstraat, the one you can see from Tervurenlaan.
name: Evening Run in Woluwe Park

description:
EVERY Friday evening from June 7th to September 27th (exception June 28th – cancelled) – Ready to roll at 8pm.

Weather permitting! (see links below for confirmation).

Open to Skaters, Cyclists and Longboards.

The event is typically split into two parts, the first section from Place Polaerts (in front of the Palais de Justice) along and through the relatively flat streets of Louise, Chatelain and the city side of Uccle, reaching Toison d'Or for the first pause. This first section is ideal for beginners to be able to give the parade a try (Being able to brake sufficiently is advisable though!). After the break the pace can step up a little and some hills and tunnels can be found on the routes (there is a bus that you can hop on and off if you want to skip certain parts or just get too tired).

Safety first:
The parade is flanked by staff and police who keep the traffic away and help to make sure no one is left behind. There are first aiders and even an ambulance, should they be needed. Everything is done to ensure your safety, but take precautions. helmets and knee, elbow & wrist guards are recommended kit. Best advice is to control your speed! Most accidents occur when people begin to go too fast and are unable to brake…

Skate and Bike rental (for a fee) is available from the start point (look for the black van from ‘TWIN’ shop). I Recommend that you turn up early to ensure they have your size though. Vilo bikes are also an option.

Each week around 6pm on the day the event will be confirmed or cancelled (if weather conditions are not appropriate) via the website:
www.belgiumrollers.com

You can also find further information (actually sometimes a little more accurate!) on http://www.rouliroula.com/forum/viewforum.php?f=295 (This is the forum of the local skating club, mostly in French, but you can find most topics on here for anything skate related in the region).

ps. There are also parades weekly in Namur and Hasselt and occasionally also in Tournai, Leuven, Tienen, Oostende, Charleroi, Nivelles, Antwerp and Brain L’Alleud - more details of those will be on the website.
how_to_find_us: Aim to meet in front of the monument in Poelaertplein (the side facing the roadside/tramlines) by 7:50pm
name: Roller Bike Parade

description:
Hi ! I'd been living here for two weeks and I'm going to do this race in La Roche en Ardenne.. anyone is going to do it and hs a place in his car for me? (I'm living in Leuven but it is not problem take the car in Brussels).
Thanks a lot!

If we are 10 people (so far, we are :) We will have the whole racing course for us.

If anyone is around this weekend, and feel like spending some adrenaline behind the steeringwheel, feel free to join!

We will do about 10k at a 10km/hr pace, and much of the route is on trails in the park. We may split in fast and slow groups.
Afterwards, if there is interest, Jeff will lead some stretching and boot camp exercises. Then, for those who are interested, we can go somewhere nearby for coffee and brunch. Cafe de la Presse on Av Louise has worked well in the past, and also Cafe Belga.
We meet at the ferry landing to Chalet Robinson

difficult terrain, quite hilly and wooded.
peace run : 9-10 km/h because it's technical and difficult
Ideal for trail
name: Run 12 km - Domaine Solvay

description:
Discovered this really nice trail around a water reservoir close to Cologne a couple of weeks ago. It's a great route, a few good hills, nice German forest and lovely views of the lake.

The link below is in German but there are some pictures to get a first impression of the area. 

http://www.ich-geh-wandern.de/rund-um-die-wahnbachtalsperre

You can find the spreadsheet for car sharing here:

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0ArXHJlk1Op5edEpzMlktX2J2ZEJEa0Zqd1EzSktXLXc&usp=sharing

Let's meet at this place: Seligenthaler Strasse, in 53721 Siegburg/Germany. 

The parking area doesn't have a street number, you basically follow the road "Seligenthaler Strasse" until the end where you can only go either left or right, at this point turn right and you'll see the parking area. The meeting point should be indicated on the map. Hope the link works.

http://goo.gl/maps/o6FYi
name: Hiking in the Cologne area

description:
sorry i forgot i have a temple ceremony in the morning

let's start in the afternoon.

meet under the arch

I know many people will be off hiking in Koln

 

as part of my marathon training, this Sunday I need to run 29K if you feel like joining.

I plan to run at 10K or 11K pace per hour depending on the condition.

starting from Cinquantenaire, partially follow the 20K route, but run a longer distance in the forest

I plan to start around 10:30 but can be adapted

if anyone is interested in joining the full 29K or only partially, welcome.

description:
Moderate pace run in the forest (+- 10k/h), with a 10 min warm up at the hippodrome as we will have a few hills on the route.

The meeting point is the car park at the crossroads between drève des Tumuli and drève du Comte, maybe 300 meters far from tram stop Coccinelles (94) and 10 min walk from tram stop Boondael Station/Gare (25). Just ask if you need more information on how to find the meeting point but with Google Map, it is easy to spot.

name: 10 k run in Forêt de Soignes

description:
Hi Everyone!
I'm almost done with my internship, so i will leave Brussels and go home on the 30th.
I started to run here, and now i'm really enjoying it, and want to go run further and further :) But i only ran in Cinquantenaire Park, because it was near for me and i was not sure if i go for a longer run i would arrive home. But last time i ran a bit more than 10k in 1h so i decided to finish my running experience in Bois de la Cambre. (now i'm almost sure i can do it!)
I would be very happy if someone could join, also cause for me it's easyer to run in group and i don't actually know the way :D.
Time and meeting point are possible to change, maybe the date as well, but Wednesday could be the best for me.

Anybody interested in trying the Ostende Roller Parade, last of the season? (last for Ostende - Brussels until 27th Sept)

They say meeting point is at 2pm but the parade itself starts at 3 so this should be doable with no rush for the ones among us doing La Bruxelloise in the morning. Don’t know anything about it except that the parade will be confirmed at noon the same day and that the route is flat. Maybe Matt has more to say about it ? Will post exact starting point and more details if people show interest.

Autumn is getting closer but it’s still time to enjoy both skating & the seaside!

Matt.

=======================================

 

EVERY Friday evening from June 7th to September 27th (exception June 28th – cancelled) – Ready to roll at 8pm.

Weather permitting! (see links below for confirmation).

Open to Skaters, Cyclists and Longboards.

The event is typically split into two parts, the first section from Place Polaerts (in front of the Palais de Justice) along and through the relatively flat streets of Louise, Chatelain and the city side of Uccle, reaching Toison d'Or for the first pause. This first section is ideal for beginners to be able to give the parade a try (Being able to brake sufficiently is advisable though!). After the break the pace can step up a little and some hills and tunnels can be found on the routes (there is a bus that you can hop on and off if you want to skip certain parts or just get too tired).

Safety first:
The parade is flanked by staff and police who keep the traffic away and help to make sure no one is left behind. There are first aiders and even an ambulance, should they be needed. Everything is done to ensure your safety, but take precautions. helmets and knee, elbow & wrist guards are recommended kit. Best advice is to control your speed! Most accidents occur when people begin to go too fast and are unable to brake…

Skate and Bike rental (for a fee) is available from the start point (look for the black van from ‘TWIN’ shop). I Recommend that you turn up early to ensure they have your size though. Vilo bikes are also an option.

Each week around 6pm on the day the event will be confirmed or cancelled (if weather conditions are not appropriate) via the website:
www.belgiumrollers.com

You can also find further information (actually sometimes a little more accurate!) on http://www.rouliroula.com/forum/viewforum.php?f=295 (This is the forum of the local skating club, mostly in French, but you can find most topics on here for anything skate related in the region).

ps. There are also parades weekly in Namur and Hasselt and occasionally also in Tournai, Leuven, Tienen, Oostende, Charleroi, Nivelles, Antwerp and Brain L’Alleud - more details of those will be on the website.

description:
For those who missed the Paris-Versailles run, and aren't ready for the triathlon that same weekend, try this fun 5km.
[from their web site] The Color Run™, also known as the “Happiest 5K on the Planet”, is a 5k run where thousands of runners – all starting in a white T-shirt – get covered in a cloud of color powder which colordip them from head to toe. Once the runner finishes the fun continues at the "Color Festival", where more color powder is thrown in the air, making every runner look like a walking rainbow.
The first The Color Run™ took place in Phoenix (US) in January 2012. That year more than 53 American cities hosted this event, giving[masked] runners the chance to take part in this unique concept. This year The Color Run™ crosses over to Europe, with events in Germany, Netherlands, France and the UK. And for the first time – in Brussels!
The organization of the Belgian The Color Run™ is in the hands of Golazo sports, who organizes 28 running events in Belgium this year. Managing Director Christophe Impens: “The Color Run™ is a fantastic experience that attracts hundreds of thousands runner worldwide. This sporty festival is part of our strategy as we like to approach our running events in an original manner. We are convinced that this concept will be hugely popular in Belgium. It is the perfect combination of fun and sport.”
Participants run or walk 5 km at their own tempo and can start freely between 14.30hrs and 16.30hrs. There will be no timing, this run is purely about having fun. After the finish, the party will break loose and by way of regular ‘color blasts’ participants will create their own impressive color clouds. Various dj’s on the podium will provide a typical popular Belgian festival atmosphere.
A maximum of 8.000 Color Runners can take part on 29 September in Brussels. The Color Run™ generally attracts a young public, and in the United States 80% of the participants are women.
The registrations for the first Belgian The Color Run™ open Tuesday 13 August at 10am on www.thecolorrun.be.

Practical
Location: Tour & Taxis, Havenlaan - Brussels
Timing:
12hrs: opening Color Festival
14hrs – 16hrs: free start The Color Run™
20hrs: finish Color Festival
name: The Color Run - Brussels

description:
This looks really nice and was passed to me by my work colleague who says the club would like to have non-orienteers participating in their November brank holiday weekend orienteering race - and I thought lots of you would be interested!

You can take part in any (or all) of the three days.
Info here:

Altaïr CO organise les 3 Jours de la Forêt de Soignes de course d’orientation les 9, 10 et 11 novembre. La plus belle série de 3 courses en Brabant.

Etape 1 des 3JFS :
Le samedi 9 novembre 2013 http://www.frso.be/course.php?id=1613 . Organisé par le club ASUB. ASUB demande une pré-inscription via le club de l’affilié avant le 3 novembre. Si tu veux, je peux remplir pour toi (et ton amie) la demande de pré-inscription. Le rendez-vous est à la salle “De Bosuil” Witherendreef 1, 3090 Jezus-Eik (Notre Dame au Bois). Le coût de l’inscription est à payer sur place (5 euros + la location d’une plaquette “emit” (2 euros) pour le poinçonnage électronique.
Il y a possibilité de faire des RandOrientations (randonnées d’orientation) de 4 ou 7 km à vol d’oiseau. Initiation à l’orientation à 10 h. Les départs se font entre 8h45 et 11 h. Prévoir du temps à passer à l’inscription au secrétariat qui ouvre à 8h. On retire les balises du bois dès 13h.

Etape 2 des 3JFS :
Le dimanche 10 novembre http://www.frso.be/course.php?id=1615. Organisé par ALTAÏR CO. Altaïr ne demande pas de pré-inscription mais c’est préférable pour ne pas à devoir éventuellement recopier les postes sur sa carte. Le rendez-vous est à l’entrée du parc Solvay, Chaussée de Bruxelles, 111 à 1310 La Hulpe. Le coût de l’inscription est gratuit pour les membres d’ALTAÏR CO sauf la location de la plaquette emit qui appartient à la FRSO.
Il y a possibilité de faire des RandOrientations (randonnées d’orientation) de 4 ou 7 km. Départs et arrivées comme pour la 1e étape.

Etape 3 des 3JFS et course Sprint (course en ville):

Le lundi 11 novembre 3e étape http://www.frso.be/course.php?id=1614 et course sprint http://www.frso.be/course.php?id=1692. Organisé par ASUB. Rendez-vous Royal Wellington Club, Avenue d'Hougoumont 14, 1180 Uccle pour la 3e étape. Un balisage (flèches blanc et rouge) est prévu à partir du Carrefour de la Chaussée de Waterloo (N5) et de la Drève Saint-Hubert.
Il est possible de participer après à la course sprint qui se passe à l’École du Homborch, Avenue d'Homborchveld 34, 1180 Uccle. Il y a un balisage au départ du Royal Wellington Club (étape du matin des 3 Jours de la Forêt de Soignes).
Coût de l’inscription : 5 euros si une seule course. 7 euros pour les 2 courses. Inscription sur place.

description:
STAIRCLIMBING EVENT

For only 15 Euros, here is your chance to climb 30 Floors (466 stairs) up to the top of the Sheraton Brussels Hotel, one of the tallest buildings in Belgium, and then take the very fast Otis elevator back down! 


All funds go to “Road to Awareness” which is the partnership between UNICEF and the associates of Starwood Hotels.  With the funds raised this year Starwood and UNICEF aim to support 20 schools in Nigeria, directly benefitting an estimated 3,000 nomadic children, and 15 schools in Cameroon where more than 5,000 children will have access to literacy and numeracy training. The funds will also be used to organise awareness-raising campaigns about the importance of going to school, and to train 150 teachers.  See 

www.roadtoawareness.com

 for further info on the projects. 

What:  StairClimbing Race up 30 floors to the top of the Sheraton Brussels Hotel – for UNICEF Road to Awareness (€15 to charity).

There will be two rest-stops (if needed).  Each participant will receive refreshment as well as a certificate of completion at the top.

Where:

Sheraton Brussels Hotel, Place Rogier 3, 1210 Brussels

When:

Sunday 17th November 2013, individual slots from 9am to 12noon (Hint: It takes around 5 minutes for the average person to climb to the top of the 30 floors). 

Register: 

www.sheratonbrussels.com/stairclimb2013 

(choose English/French/Dutch)

Prizes:

The fastest male participant and the fastest female participant will be crowned “The King and The Queen of the Sheraton Brussels for a Year” – meaning that each month for one year from December 2013, the King and the Queen will each have the choice to receive either one free weekend night (one Friday, Saturday or Sunday night; room-only and based upon availability) at the Sheraton Brussels Hotel for maximum two people;  or alternatively they can receive 1000 free SPG Points each month which can be utilized for hotel stays & more as part of the Starwood Preferred Guest loyalty program.There will also be a prize for the “most original” runner, and other special categories.


In addition a number of other great prizes will be drawn from a list of ALL participants of the Stair Climb, so anyone can be a winner! 


Starting after the race around[masked], there will also be the Road to Awareness Lunch available for only 7.50 Euros (5 Euros for children) at the top of the stairs with the magical view over the city! (Lunch tickets available for sale on the day)


If any of those who ran this last year would like to provide feedback, please do so in a comment. Thanks!

description:
Hi Brussels Runners,
Greetings from Wellington Running Meetup - WoRM (NZ)!
We would like to invite you and your running group to help us do something really, really awesome…
Join us for the 3rd Worldwide Companion Run.

It started three years ago when Ash (one of WoRM’s organisers) went away for 6 months and really missed running with the group. One day, we had an idea.

Why not run at the same time just in different locations?
We soon realised that this could in fact, be something really cool.
That’s how Worldwide Companion Run was born.

In 2011 we had a humble 35 runners in 12 countries.
In 2012 we had nearly 150 in close to 35 countries.
And this year, we’re aiming to make it much, much BIGGER.
Our goal is at least 1000 runners in at least 100 cities and at least 50 countries.

The concept is very simple:
Wherever you are at 4PM GMT on the 27th of November 2013, run or walk 5k.
The choice of the route is up to you.
Get some friends to join you and make it funky. Yes, funky.
Take some photos/videos of your run and share them with other runners from around the globe. Show us your running reality!

How do you join in the fun?
Spread the word by creating a Worldwide Companion Run event in your Meetup on 27 or 28th November (depending on where around the globe you are).
Join our event on Facebook - this is the event’s headquarters :-)
Joining the event on Facebook will keep you in the loop and that’s where we’ll be posting the photos, videos and much more!
Participate in this unique running movement!
Some speculate that we could even move the Earth!
We have also created a tool which will help you organise a group and put your spot on the map. To set up your run, please use our RunningHub Companion Tool. It will also work out the time for you and allow you to invite friends and if you wish so, open the run to other runners nearby. This way you can also promote your Meetup Group!

Who’s behind WCR2013?
This event is organised entirely by WoRM runners for runners - no fees, no sponsors, no entry forms. Just you and the rest of the world. Together.
Join in, pass it on and get involved. Whether you do it alone or with a group of 100+... the more the merrier!

If you have any questions or would like some advice on how to prepare for WCR2013, feel free to drop me a line: [masked]

Cheers from runningly awesome New Zealand,
Ewa (aka Crazychick), Ash and Brent
WoRM Runnership Team
name: Worldwide Companion Run

description: Its been a very long time since I have done a Saturday run and I really need to get back into it ... so, let's run a 10km. The pace will be decided on the spot, depending on the group. We might split into two or three groups to cover a different distance and a different speed.

description:
**We have enough for the minimum sign-up, but still places left if you want to join...**


Ever wanted to have a go at Ice Hockey but never had the chance?
Now is that chance!
Friday 6th December there is organised a session of ‘fun hockey’.
If you’ve skated on ice a little before (or can inline skate), then come along to this – All the equipment is included (skates too) and so you’ll be kitted out with all the protection you need not to worry about falling on the ice. There will be a quick run down of the rules and then the group, divided into teams, will face-off for a game :-)
This is for pure fun, rules are ‘no-contact’ (so not like you see on the TV where the players try to kill each other!) and so just suit up and let the hilarity commence as you all slip and slide on the ice…
You don’t have to be an expert on the ice and believe it or not the hockey stick will give you some more in the way of balance!

Time : arrive 21.00 – ready to start playing at 21.45 until 23.15
Place : Leest – Mechelen (will need to go by car or car-pool)
Price : 25euro includes the entrance fee, hockey kit, stick and ice skates.

Register your presence here, but more importantly go to the facebook link below and ‘join’ there – this is not my initiative (though is a friend of mine) so he needs to know who is coming via that link:

https://www.facebook.com/events/1408274199408940/
If you’ve any questions please ask directly on the FB link – Johnny is Flemish but speaks perfect English too and will be happy to answer any questions

Numbers are limited, but also there needs to be a minimum number to make this work – so give it a go and join the fun :-)

(If needs be we can start a car-pool)
name: 'Fun' Ice Hockey!

description:
18 C and sunny. plan is to go by train (traffic will be pretty bad most likely).
8:55 train (from gare central) to Ostend, then coast tram to De Haan. We should be there before 11:00.

There is a 15-20 km trail that goes by the coast and through some forests towards Knokke. The hike + lunch should take 4-5 hours. We can then take the tram back to Ostend and a return train or take a train from Knokke. This part is not clear yet.
The tourist office in De Haan will be open from 9:30 to 12:00. We can stop by and get info and maps. So, we should be back 7-8pm I would expect.
name: Coastal hike

description:
It is nice to run, but why not spice up running with a little bit of cultural tourism. I propose going to the Waterloo Lion's Mound monument and run back from there. The monument stands where Napoleon was defeated for the last time in the battle of Waterloo. It is a 43 m height artificial hill with a Lion monument on top of it. The view over the battlefield is said to be superb from there.

The map of the planned route: http://goo.gl/maps/nXqv5

The first 3.8 km is on roads between plough lands, then 2.8 km crossing a village, the last 13.3 km is in our much loved forest. The pace is intended to be around 5:40 minutes/km.

We take the bus 365a at 8:35 from Brussels Midi to Waterloo Monument Gordon. We will arrive 9:26. The stop is 300 meters away from the monument. Time table for the bus: http://www.infotec.be/hastinfo/published/Document.axd?document=6965

We would take a look at the monument, going up, having some fun, breathing history in deeply. See what we get for the 9 Euro entrance fee. We start between 10:00 and 10:20 from there and I assume two hours will be enough to get back to the park, or to the coffee house.

Monument prices: http://waterloo-tourisme.com/Public1/index.php/en/component/content/article?id=8 Budget: 4 Euro for the bus (it might be eight, but I couldn’t figure it out), 9 Euro for the entrance to the monument.

The weather forecast is promising:  http://www.accuweather.com/en/be/brussels/27581/weekend-weather/27581
name: Running from the Waterloo Lion's Mound to Brussels (20 km + getting lost)

We meet at the ferry landing , we will run 10km at a pace of 10k/h on average. Depending on who turns up, we may split into a "main" group and a "relaxed" group with a lower pace.

This is a hidden gem of a run ! I ran it last year with a friend and really enjoyed how fun, beautiful and well organized it was. This flat course is along the serene Sûre River in Diekirch with not too many participants ( only about 400 for both races) and even a pace-setter ( 1h 40min). Sorry for the last minute meet up, I have two more places in my car if anybody is interested. We are leaving Brussels around 10 am. More info here : www.foyernordstadsemi.lu

For those who will pay on race day, it's 20 Euros for the Half Marathon and 16 Euros for the 10 km. If you don't want to stress too much (there might be a small line to register) and still have adequate warm up time, maybe come a little earlier like 13:00-13:15 or so.

I'll be wearing a bright orange shirt right at the entrance of the stadium so you can't miss me. I wish everyone a fantastic race ! Its flat and not too crowded, so if you're prepared and the weather cooperates, YOU CAN expect to do your best time !!! :D

also in coordination with the Lux Expat Meet Up :
http://www.meetup.com/Luxembourg-expats-and-repats/events/165197362/

Hi guys,

Anyone would be interested to join me for a running session? Weather is getting warmer and it´s becoming challenging to run alone :- ))

Start Time & Location: 20.00 , Under the Arc of Parc du Cinquantenaire
Route: From Parc du Cinquantenaire to the direction of Woluwe Parc. Once we reach to the bridge, we might take left to the Green Path (a part of Promenade Verte I guess) , after a few km´s on the green path we might also run a bit in Woluwe Parc Finish Location: Montgomery Square or Parc du Cinquanteneaire
Pace: A very relaxed pace 
Distance: ~ 12 Km

Cheers,

Mert
name: 12K Evening Run

description:
Hi everybody,

This meetup is not (only) about running, but about building up your endurance. After a short warm up (15 min running and exercises) I propose to do some group exercises following the scheme below:

(40 sek exercise - 20 sek rest)*2
Totalling of 30 min.

(This is for a start, if you would like it we would move to a scheme (45/15)*2 for an hour, next time though)

The exercises would vary. They are simple and we are not going to use any special equipment. But I would still suggest it would be challenging to do them, as you would have very limited time to restore your pulse!

Such training suits perfectly long-distance runners. I do not recommend it to those not used to high-intensity training as it could be even bad for your heart if not prepared and have too much enthusiasm. We would meet Under the Arc of Parc du Cinquantenaire and after the warm-up would move to some open ground in the park.

You might want to bring a towel with you as you might get dirty while doing some exercises on the ground.

In case of bad weather (rain) the meetup would be substituted for running in the Park.

See you there!

Aljona

description:

If you fancy being active on Friday evening, then come to the two small white houses at the beginning of Bois de la Cambre. The tram stop Legrand is nearby.

Suggested distance is 10 km at a pace of around 5'40''; however, this is open for discussion and we adapt to the group's wishes. The route runs towards Forêt des Soignes and passes the hippodrome. Feel free to bring headlamps or bike lights along.

We can also discuss having well-deserved drinks at a nice place later at night.

And remember: the longer you run, the funnier it gets :-)

description:
Hike on Easter Sunday, taking the train to Godinne and then walking Godinne to Dinant. The route is part of the GR 126, a Grand-Randonnée walk that goes from Brussels to Membre-sur-Semois in the very south of Belgium
The route looks very nice, going along the river and passing by the original brewing place of Leffe beer among other places:

Gare de Godinne - Ancienne Gare des Forges - Evrehailles - Ruines de Poilvache - Houx - Awagne - Le Buc (Loyers) - Abbaye de Leffe - Citadelle de Dinant The distance is 22km, so be prepared to walk for 4-5 hours. I have the book in both French and Dutch, so no worries here. (If anyone does have a more detailed map of the area this would be helpful)

http://www.grsentiers.org/topo-guides/30-gr-126-bruxelles-namur-membre-sur-semois.html

Meeting point 8.45 at Gare Centrale to take the train together at 9.07 (tbc.) Train arrives at 10.30, so we can expect to be in Dinant by mid-afternoon. The plan would be to spend a little time in Dinant to soak up the sunshine and then take the train back to Brussels.
name: Easter Sunday hike - Godinne to Dinant

description: Easter Day: I am planning to do this trail of 28k (already registered), 21k also possible. The races are: Saint-Omer - Cassel, 28k, starting at 9h, and Watten-Cassel, 21k starting at 9h30. The idea is that runners from both races run together the last part (actually more like walking together since it is a steep path). It is not an easy one, but promissing :-) Join me if you can. Travel by train also possible, with possibility for accommodation. Lovers of some other activities e.g. hikking can also join, very nice & green area. 4 separate hikking races (randonees) from 8k to 21k also organised the same morning. For more details: http://www.course-alternative.fr/concept_104.htm

description:
Hi there!

My name is Nicolas. I am a passionate orienteer, practicing this sport since many years. I recently came across this Meetup page, and thought a lot of people here could be interested in trying orienteering. I read that some of you already tried it in November, on the occasion of some orienteering races organised in the Forêt de Soignes: http://www.meetup.com/Brussels-Runners/events/146510462/

Orienteering is an outdoor adventure and navigation sport that combines two things: running and map reading. As it happens, every year during the spring and summer months small orienteering events are being organised in parks, forests and urban areas in and around Brussels. Every Friday evening an orienteering training is organised by one of the two Brussels based orienteering clubs (Altaïr C.O. or Asub Orientation). These gatherings are perfect opportunities for beginners to discover the sport. Or in general for everyone, just to relax after the workweek, while enjoying a natural environment.

The calendar can be found here: http://www.asub-orientation.org/challenge_ete/CalendrierChallengeete2014.html

Often people are a bit deterred by the map reading component. I would like to stress that the basics of orienteering are not difficult to pick up at all, and that initiators will be present to explain the fundamentals of map reading.

At the events we organise there's always possibility to run or walk, alone or in group, with or without time registration. Free start between 18h and 19h15. Different courses are proposed: from 2 km to 7 km ("as the crow flies"). Entry fee is 3 euros.

This friday for instance I am organising an orienteering session in Forêt de Soignes, in La Hulpe. Meetup place is the parking at Ferme du Chateau, Drève de la Ramée - 1410 La Hulpe.
https://www.google.com/maps/place/50%C2%B043'50.9%22N+4%C2%B027'03.5%22E/@50.730804,4.450977,2809m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x0

So don't miss out on this occasion :) Every event is very approachable for novices. Runners who like running, trail running, and outdoor activities, will for sure appreciate orienteering too :) All you need is a pair of good running shoes, long trousers, and a spirit for adventure!

Don't hesitate to contact me for any further information, here or via email ([masked])

In September, on the occasion of Brussels Car Free Sunday, we also organize an orienteering race in Brussels City Centre. I will create a Meetup soon :) In the meanwhile, all info and entries here: http://brussels-orienteering.be/en/

Further information on orienteering can also be found on Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orienteering

And, lastly, the website of the Walloon-Brussels Orienteering Federation (FRSO): http://frso.be/

Hope to see you soon in a forest near Brussels!

Nicolas Spiliers

description:
Dear all,

Thank you for joining this meetup event.

I suggest we meet after 9:30 INSIDE the Cinquantenaire Park, after the main entrance next to Merode (in front of the Canadian embassy). Those who have a Brussels Runners T-shirt, do not hesitate to wear it.

After the race we can gather at the same place, after we have finish the race.

Once we would have reached a critical mass we will move to some pub to have a drink/food. I will give a phone number later for those who may arrive later.

SOME USEFUL INFORMATION:

1-  You can check the 20K route here: http://www.20kmdebruxelles.be/en/the-race/route/

Remark that the last 2/3 Km are uphill!

2-  You may pick your race number up, at race headquarters, rue de la Chapelle, 17, Brussels, between 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Monday to Friday. On Saturday 17 May and Sunday 18 you can pick up your number in the 20km village located in the Parc du Cinquantenaire.

3-  There is a changing room, free of charge, in the Musée Royal de l’Armée (Royal Army Museum), located in the Parc du Cinquantenaire. Only individuals wearing a race number will be admitted. Seems that there are no lockers to drop your bags there.

4-  If the weather predictions are right, the weather is going to be very nice for running. Sunny day and 13 to 17 C 
http://www.wunderground.com/cgi-bin/findweather/getForecast?query=50.833302,4.333300&sp=IBRUXELL9

5-  Parking is expected to be rather complicated, so come by public transport if possible.

For more information visit their website http://www.20kmdebruxelles.be/en/the-race/reglement/

I wish you good luck on Sunday!

To sum up:-

• Those who registered before 31 May are entitled to receive some discounts on their registration fees.


• All participants will get free events t-shirt.


• For those who registered before 31 May are also entitled to have their personalised race number.

Quick guides on how to sign up and register for the race:

• Go to the Midzomernachtrun 2014 when you've landed on the website.

• Scroll your cursor down to Inschrijvingen and click.


• You're to be given 3 options on how are you going to register. If you're going to sign up as an individual, click Schrijf in under Particulier. The rest are as sports organisations, like sport clubs and the other one is if you want to register as a team with your friends.


• You can choose your preferred language once you've landed on the next page. The options are on your upper far right. They have Dutch, English and French.

I hope it helps to those who have difficulties signing up for the race. Hope to see you guys there! Do mail me if you have further questions regarding of the registrations.

description:
I propose to join us in 6h rogaining event in Ardennes close to French-Belgian border. All you need is a compass (true, you need to have some navigation skills to be able to use it), some water, food and your endurance to last for 6 h in hilly terrain. Well, you will need to find a good friend to go with you as well, as rogaining is a team sport.

The aim is to find as much checkpoints as possible within the 6h time limit. You will have half an hour to plan you route before the mass start would be given at 9.00. Those finished after 6h time limit, would be penalised and there overall score would be reduced.

Rogaining is really good training for long-distance and trail runners, orienteerers as well as hikers (who take this sport easy and enjoy the terrain).

Additional information and registration http://www.asub-orientation.org/documents/ASUB_First_Rogaine.html
Flyer http://www.asub-orientation.org/documents/ASUB_ROGAINE_FLYER_en-fr.pdf

I welcome any additional questions!
___________
Rogaining is a sport of long distance cross-country navigation, involving both route planning and navigation between checkpoints using a variety of map types. In a rogaine, teams of 2-5 people choose which checkpoints to visit within a time limit with the intent of maximizing their score. Teamwork, endurance, competition and an appreciation for the natural environment are features of the sport. Championship rogaines are 24 hours long, however rogaines can be as short as 2 hours. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogaining)
name: 6 h Rogain (long-distance orienteering) in Ardennes

description:
There is an orienteering event organised every week by clubs Asub & Altair. Orienteering is basically a combination of running and navigating. This Friday the meeting point is at the stade/stadium Fallon in Woluwe. Unlike most recent orienteering events in the forest, I expect this to be a bit more “urban”, but I don’t have any official details about it.


There are maps for different difficulty levels. Most are designed for running, but they usually provide a route that can be done walking as well. Just arrive somewhere between 18:00 and 19:15, you'll get a few minutes of explanation and off you go. It usually takes about an hour for a beginners course.
Cost: 3 euro each, to be paid to the organizer (not me). People at the stadium may or may not know about the event, just look for a few parked cars with a small orange "flag", and a table, boxes & people around it and talk to them.

description:
Orienteering is basically a combination of running and navigating. There is an orienteering event organised every week until the end of September by clubs Asub & Altair. This Friday the meeting point is at Groenendaal station (between Boitsfort and La Hulpe). It is the Flemish part of the forest, we will not be allowed to go off the paths this time.

The organisers will provide maps for different difficulty levels. Most are designed for running, but they usually provide a route that can be done walking as well. Just arrive somewhere between 18:00 and 19:15, you'll get a few minutes of explanation (ask for it if they don't) and off you go. It usually takes about an hour for a beginners course.

Cost: 3 euro each, to be paid to the organizer (not me).
Look for a few parked cars with a small orange "flag", and a table, boxes & people around it and talk to them.

Link to the exact meeting point (taken from the website of the organisation):
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Groenendaal+Station/@50.7665782,4.4489404,755m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x47c3da7dd3346bc3:0xee9725ff849df649

Read more about orienteering in Nicolas's first post:
http://www.meetup.com/Brussels-Runners/events/180928852/

The calendar with the weekly events:
http://www.asub-orientation.org/challenge_ete/CalendrierChallengeete2014.html
name: Orienteering in Groenendaal

description:
Many of you know these survival runs already. For those who don't, this is an excellent occasion to try your hands at it!

I'd like to invite you to join me for this special , one-off edition which will be held in the Citadel of Diest (about 60Km from Brussels): dark corridors, catacombs, deep channels... sounds like fun, right? 8 Km, 40 obstacles. All participants get a t-shirt and a military beret. Bag storage, changing rooms and showers are envisaged (no icy hoses this time around!)

More info on the race here: http://gladiatorrun.be/combat-edition/

If we register quickly we can make the second wave (each has 150 participants), which should avoid long queues at obstacles.

From next week the price will be 45 Eur, but there's a 10 Eur early bird discount until March 24th, and you can save an extra 5 Eur if you use the promo code "Gladiator" at the end of the registration (so 30 Eur instead of 45). So make up your minds, let's register a team over the week-end! :)

We won't do a team registration for practical reasons, but we can run together if we're in the same wave. So hurry up, register here: http://bibtiming.be/registration/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=115 and don't forget the code "Gladiator", which grants you an additional 5 € discount on top of the early bird price until Monday 24th at 24:00 (it becomes more expensive later). Wave 2 should be between the 151st and the 300th participant, let's try and all be in the same one.

Do not request an elite starting box unless your intention is to compete with speedy athletes.

There will be a board with the participants' names where you can check your number before picking it up. Let's try and meet close to the board (it will be busy, but somewhere in the general area) between 12.15 and 12.30. I'll wear my black "Blood, Mud and Beers" T-shirt.
name: Gladiator Run Combat Edition

description:
On Car Free Sunday, Brussels will host the first edition of The Brussels Orienteering Meeting (BOM). If you like running and you like Brussels, then try out this particular event! :) You will run a course as always, only this time there's no fixed route: you'll read a city map. Starting will be by interval (every minute, like in cycling time trials). Normal running competitions are often organised on big avenues, but we on the other hand have the opportunity to organise our event right in the city centre. In a Car Free Brussels, this promises to be an exciting experience.

The BOM offers a lot:
- The map is understandable by all, and will cover the entire Brussels Pentagon.
- We offer 9 different courses to choose from, going from 2,4km up to 9,6km.
- You can run alone, but also in group, or you can choose to walk. All ages will be present, from children at the age of 10 to adults of 70 and older. The BOM is suited for competitive as well as for recreational runners!
- Secretariat and start are situated at Place Rouppe, at 10min walking distance from the Gare du Midi.
- A comic book figures course is also offered.

Here is an info document for people running for the first time with a map. It also explains how you can register:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/ea9sr7wlllhzmqa/debEN2.png?dl=0

For the location, distances and starting hours I refer to our website: http://brussels-orienteering.be/

Event on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/736809883016968/?fref=ts

Entries will close soon, so don’t hesitate and try out this unique occasion to get to know Brussels in a special way! :) Already more than 350 people have decided to do so!

Myself, I will be available during the entire event to give information and answer questions.

Don’t hesitate to contact me for any questions you might have right now! Here or via email ([masked])

Hope to see you september 21st!

Nicolas Spiliers
name: Brussels Orienteering Meeting - on Car Free Sunday

Le très attendu Trail des Hautes Fagnes, jugé par beaucoup comme l'un des plus beaux de Belgique, aura lieu comme chaque année le dernier samedi de septembre à Xhoffraix.

Deux distances de 14 et 38 km seront porposées aux participants et leur permettront de traverser vallées boisées, rivières bucoliques et hauts plateaux de nos superbes Hautes Fagnes.

Le trail se cractérise par la diversité de ses paysages et le cadre naturel exceptionnel de la région, mais aussi par le caractère convivial et "ouvert à tous" de son organisation.

Découvrez ou redécouvrez cette magnifique course nature où le plaisir de courir et la convivialité sont les maîtres mots.

http://www.traildeshautesfagnes.be/

description:
Fellow Runners / Newbies... Come join me for a little run around the CINQUANTENAIRE park to celebrate the arrival of the beautiful colours and smells of Autumn in Brussels...

FOR THE TRUELY BEGINNERS (09h45):

Come and join me for a 2.5 km jog around the park, it will be at a very comfortable pace. There is no shame in wanting to try it out. We all have to start somewhere and work our way up - it only gets better... ;-)

FOR THE OTHER RUNNERS (10h15): 

I will split the bunch in 2 groups as there will likely be a variation of runners:

(1) for the 8-9 km/h runners (2-3 turns around the park) and;
(2) for the 10-11 km/h runners (2-3 turns around the park)

ON THE DAY OF THE RUN

(1) We will meet in front of the AUTOWORLD Museum doors (09h45 beginners, 10h15 for the others)
(2) Do a little warm-up;
(3) Run while meeting and chatting with great people;
(4) Little after-run cool-down;
(5) Start off the week on a good note.

I usually like to run on Saturdays but my schedule only permits for Sunday this time... Hopefully this doesn't interfere with your other social commitments...

Hope to see you in a couple of weeks - lets make this a healthy habit!!!

Those of you who ran an Urban Trail in Antwerp or Bruges are familiar with the concept: running through the streets of the city and its buildings, as a new way to discover it.

You will not be able to establish a PB, but you will get to see the city and have fun!

After the race everyone receives breakfast! (last time it was chocolate milk, an apple and honey-bread, I believe).

4000 places available: the day is still very far down the line, but the one in Antwerp sold out months in advance, so hurry up if you're interested!

Start in waves at: 9:30, 9:50, 10:10 and 10:30.

Registration here: http://www.sport.be/dhurbantrailseries/mons/2014/fr/inschrijven/
name: Mons Urbain Trail (10K)

description:
Another after work run is on: The suggested distance is around 11 km at a pace of 5'20''.

Meeting point is the baywatch chair at Montgomery; (When you come from Merode it is on the right side of the roundabout.) If you own a head light or bike lamp, it does not hurt to bring it along.

This time the route is slightly different: We are going to head down to the tram museum, up to the windmill and back on the green way before we are going to drag ourselves back to Montgomery.

description:
T.G.I.F. - If you want to fight the inner couch potato and have an active Friday eve, just join us at the bois de la cambre. The suggested distance is a bit more than 11 km and the speed is around 11.5 km/h.

Starting point is at the two white houses at the entrance of the forest. The tram stop "Legrand" is a stonethrow away.

Please bring a head lamp or bike light along if you have one. We will head to the lakes and the hippodrome before rushing through the forêt de soignes. Eventually, we return to where we have started from.

description:
I take the liberty to organize this event this week, for those willing to go for a moderate run on Wednesday in spite of the presumably bad weather. The plan is to run 11-12 km in approximately 1 hour. We will take Avenue Tervuren down to Woluwe Park and then we can either head to the Rouge Cloître or run along the Promenade Verte, we can decide there.

For those not familiar with it, the Baywatch chair is at the tip of the green area in the middle of Boulevard Saint Michel.
name: Wednesday evening run: "I've been looking for freedom"

description:
T.G.I.F. - If you want to fight the inner couch potato and have an active Friday eve, just join us at the bois de la cambre. The suggested distance is a bit more than 11 km and the speed around 11.5 km/h.

We will meet this time at the entrance of the forest next to the two white houses. The tram stop "Legrand" is a stonethrow away.

Headlamps and bike lights do not hurt. One will be there for sure.

We will pass the lake and run down(hill) the drève the deux montagnes. On the way back from the forêt de soignes, we say hello to the hippodrome and return to the start.

description:
Let's run some laps around the Parc du Cinquantenaire. This can be an easy recovery run if you did some long running Sunday, or a moderate run if you did not.

Five laps is just over 11 km, but you can also stop after the fourth one, or run a few more laps if you feel like it. The suggested pace is 5'00" to 5'30" per km, but it will be adapted to the group. Meeting point is the gate next to Merode. You will not need a lamp, but you can bring one if it makes you feel more comfortable.

description:
Orienteering is a combination of running and navigating. Each year, the two Brussels-based orienteering clubs organize three races in three different parts of the Sonian Forest. The first one is this Sunday, in Auderghem.

At 10:00 an initiation tour will start, where some experienced orienteers will teach the basics of orienteering. Afterwards, you can run or walk a course yourself if you like, alone or in group.

Cost is €5 per stage.

Meeting point is at the Rouge-Cloître Abbey, 1160 Auderghem.

Info about the first stage of the 3 days, on the website of the Francophone orienteering federation (FRSO): http://frso.be/course.php?id=1683

Info about the other stages (Nov. 9 and Nov. 11) can be found on the same website (www.frso.be).

The event on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/events/757759260952569/?fref=ts

Wikipedia-article on orienteering: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orienteering

description: Let's run a few laps at Cinquantenaire Park. I propose five laps (just over 11 km) at a pace between 5'00" and 5'30" per km (speed of 11.5 to 12 km/h). You can obviously stop after three of four laps, this is one of the advantages of running in a park. And if you would prefer a slower pace, feel free to comment and maybe this attracts more people and we can split in smaller groups. If it does not, I can run a couple of laps at 6 min/km, that should not hurt.

description:
Orienteering is a combination of running and navigating. Each year, the two Brussels-based orienteering clubs organize three races in three different parts of the Sonian Forest. The second one is this Sunday, in Hoeilaart.

At 10:00 an initiation tour will start, where an experienced orienteer will teach you the basics of orienteering. This tour will take +- 1h30, and will cover a distance of 4-5km. It will mainly consist of walking.

If you already have done some orienteering in your life (or just don't like walking), I will be there too to give some explanations, after which you can subscribe for a real course. Distances go from 3 to 9km (as the crow flies).

You can participate alone, or in group.

Cost is €5.
Meeting place is the Centre Equestre "Le Relais" - Groenendaalsesteenweg,[masked] Hoeilaart.

Info about this second stage of the 3 days, on the website of the Francophone orienteering federation (FRSO): http://www.frso.be/course.php?id=1684

The event on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/events/757759260952569/?fref=ts and https://www.facebook.com/events/459116127561988/?fref=ts

Wikipedia-article on orienteering: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orienteering

Meetup article of the first stage: http://www.meetup.com/Brussels-Runners/events/216221832/
name: Orienteering in the Forêt de Soignes (2nd stage)

description:
For those working on Monday, and for those who don't but still would like to run in the evening, let's run a few laps at Cinquantenaire Park. We meet at the Merode entrance.

Five laps are just over 11 km, but you can just stop when you have had enough. The proposed pace is between 5' and 5'30"/km. If you would like to run a bit slower, let us know and maybe we can split in groups.

Unfortunately, this week it might not rain.
name: Monday evening run at Cinquantenaire (up to 11 km)

description: For those looking to kickstart their week-end, consider this night race by headlamp - always a fun challenge. Transportation to the start of the race either by train or car. Registration is 7€, including a meal post-race. Registration must be done online by Nov 9 at: https://sites.google.com/site/traildesetoiles/le-trail-des-etoiles.

description: Trail run in Maasmechelen offering distances ranging from 7 to 42k. Truly something for everyone. Registration is cheaper online but can also be done on site. More info here: http://kraftman-triathlon.be/inschrijven.html. All info in Dutch but from what I can piece together there are aid stations, showers & parking. A winning description of the race courtesy of Google Translate: "Enjoy while jogging in nature in all its glory! In this natural setting of many rare and unusual animals live."
name: Kraftman's Marathon Trail Run (7-42k)

name: Gladiator Run 2014! :-)

description:
Hope this race is qualifying to be sent here since it's not a regular road race, it's a Stair Climbing Race :-)

What: Stair Climbing Race up 30 floors to the top of the Sheraton Brussels Hotel – for UNICEF Road to Awareness.


Runners start one at a time (not all together), but there is no fixed starting order; when you arrive at the Sheraton come to the 2nd floor to compete the registration process, and then you will get in line to start on the ground floor stairway entrance, one person starting at a time per minute. Along the stairway there will be two rest-stops (if needed). Each participant will receive refreshment as well as a certificate of completion at the top. Supporters can wait at the top 30th floor or on 2nd floor, but not in the staircase. There are changing facilities available but no showers. 

Where: Sheraton Brussels Hotel, Place Rogier 3, 1210 Brussels 

When: Sunday 23rd November 2014, individual slots from 9am to 12noon (Hint: It takes around 5 minutes for the average person to climb to the top of the 30 floors)

Registration: www.sheratonbrussels.com/stairclimb (€18 to charity via advance registration; €20 to charity on the day). 

Prizes: The fastest male participant and the fastest female participant will be crowned “The King and The Queen of the Sheraton Brussels for a Year” – meaning that each month for one year from December 2014, the King and the Queen will each have the choice to receive either one free weekend night (one Friday, Saturday or Sunday night; room-only and based upon availability) at the Sheraton Brussels Hotel for maximum two people; or alternatively they can receive 1000 free SPG Points each month which can be utilized for hotel stays & more as part of the Starwood Preferred Guest loyalty program. There will also be a prize for the “most original” runner, and other special categories. In addition a number of other great prizes will be drawn from a list of all participants of the Stair Climb.
name: Stair Climbing Race

description:
Beautiful-looking trail race around Spa, although it will be hard to appreciate the scenery by the end. Easily the best value race I've ever come across at only 10€ (that 14 cents per km!) with 4 aid stations & a hot meal at the end. And we get a point for UTMB/CCC/TDS! Not the most original name, but presumably self-explanatory as to location. Must register by 20 Nov by email or...text (?!). Either a car will be needed or take the train on Saturday (race starts crack of dawn by Belgian standards on Sunday - registration at 7 am). Feel free to message me to coordinate.
More info: http://www.courirpourleplaisir.be/html/v_3/p_1.html.
name: Olne - Spa - Olne 69k
